Caption: Fig. 1. Left: Traditional 2D projection (A) of a single artery, and 3D representation (C) of a right coronary artery tree with a rainbow color map. Right: 2D tree diagram representation (B) and equivalent 3D representation (D) of a left coronary artery tree with a diverging color map.
Table 1. Domain tasks, broken down by clinical versus research focus, of participants based on a formative qualitative user study.

Fig. 2. The three different cylindrical projection techniques presented to users during the formative qualitative user study. Top: Traditional cylindrical projection. Middle: Projection with circumference mapped to image height above the x-axis. Bottom: Projection with circumference mapped to the width of image symmetric on centerline (preferred pro- jection by users).
Fig. 6. HemoVis in the “individual” mode displaying a single artery with small tree diagram for navigation in the lower right.

Fig. 4. Color schemes presented during the qualitative user study. The rainbow scheme (A) was preferred by most since it is what they are accustomed to viewing. The next most popular scheme was the red- black diverging scale (F). The grayscale image (E) was unanimously disliked since participants assume black-and-white images to be raw radiological data, while color indicates that the data has been processed or simulated.
Fig. 5. HemoVis in the “tree” mode displaying a patient’s left coronary artery tree with color mapped to ESS.

Fig. 8. Average percent of low ESS regions identified broken down by 2D and 3D representation, and left and right artery systems. Error bars correspond to the standard error and the asterisks indicate results of statistical significance. In 3D, users were less accurate identifying re- gions in the most complex data sets (i.e., left artery systems). Whereas in 2D, performance was the same regardless of task complexity.

Fig. 10. Average rates of seconds per region to identify broken down by 2D and 3D representation, and color. Error bars correspond to the standard error and the asterisks indicate results of statistical signifi- cance. Participants were more efficient in 2D, and in 3D there was a sig- nificant difference in participant performance between color schemes.

Fig. 9. Average total time spent on each image broken down by 2D and 3D representation, and color. Error bars correspond to the stan- dard error and the asterisks indicate results of statistical significance. Participants completed tasks more quickly in 2D than 3D.
